prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Two spectral windows in the correlator are set to observe emission lines (a line per spectral window), with two additional spectral windows observing the continuum. The spectral line widths are not well restrained, thus we used the results obtained from ALMA observations of protoplanetary disks to obtain a lower limit to the line widths (Teague et al. 2015, Mathews et al. 2013).

We estimate that the exosolar systems will have a extent of 100 au; assuming the distances to the sources given in Table 1, we obtained largest angular scale structures ranging from 1.16 and 5.6 arcsecs. The chosen angular resolution of 0.58 which represents a 50 au from the host star. Ideally, this value would have been the distance to the habitable zone, however, ALMA early science is not yet capable of achieving resolution of 0.006 arcsecs within a reasonable time. The resolution we requested will allows us to distinguish between the inner and outer regions of the exosolar systems, enabling us to determine if the location of the snowline and water with respect to the location of the planets in the system.

We propose to observe four exosolar systems identified with known planets in and around the habitable zone. We will observe DCO+ v = 0 J = 3-2 (216.1158 GHz) and H2O v2 = 1 5 (5,0)-6(4,3) (232.6867 GHz) lines. Since these lines have yet to be detected in these early exosolar systems, we obtained the peak line flux value from the ALMA detection of the DCO+ line of HD 163296 (Mathews et al. 2013). Given that our sources are at a later evolutionary stage we are assuming the emission will be lower than for a protoplanetary disk, thus we estimated a value of 1.5 mJy for the peak line flux, after the continuum emission for HD 163296 at 1.3 mm was subtracted from the line detection obtained by Isella et al. (2013). In order to obtain a minimum of 5sigma detection, we set the requested sensitivity to 0.3 mJy, to achieve this sensitivity we also request the water vapor column density to be at 0.658 mm(2nd Octile) or better.
The continuum peak values are an extrapolation from the 100 micron feature detection obtained with the Herschel telescope assuming the emission from 100 microns to 1 mm follow thermal dust emission from large grains with a slope of 2.0 (Draine 2006). This estimated flux is a lower limit value.

Two spectral windows in the correlator are set to observe emission lines (a line per spectral window), with two additional spectral windows observing the continuum. The spectral line widths are not well restrained, thus we used the results obtained from ALMA observations of protoplanetary disks to obtain a lower limit to the line widths (Teague et al. 2015, Mathews et al. 2013).

We estimate that the exosolar systems will have a extent of 100 au; assuming the distances to the sources given in Table 1, we obtained largest angular scale structures ranging from 1.16 and 5.6 arcsecs. The chosen angular resolution of 0.58 which represents a 50 au from the host star. Ideally, this value would have been the distance to the habitable zone, however, ALMA early science is not yet capable of achieving resolution of 0.006 arcsecs within a reasonable time. The resolution we requested will allows us to distinguish between the inner and outer regions of the exosolar systems, enabling us to determine if the location of the snowline and water with respect to the location of the planets in the system.

We propose to observe four exosolar systems identified with known planets in and around the habitable zone. We will observe DCO+ v = 0 J = 3-2 (216.1158 GHz) and H2O v2 = 1 5 (5,0)-6(4,3) (232.6867 GHz) lines. Since these lines have yet to be detected in these early exosolar systems, we obtained the peak line flux value from the ALMA detection of the DCO+ line of HD 163296 (Mathews et al. 2013). Given that our sources are at a later evolutionary stage we are assuming the emission will be lower than for a protoplanetary disk, thus we estimated a value of 1.5 mJy for the peak line flux, after the continuum emission for HD 163296 at 1.3 mm was subtracted from the line detection obtained by Isella et al. (2013). In order to obtain a minimum of 5sigma detection, we set the requested sensitivity to 0.3 mJy, to achieve this sensitivity we also request the water vapor column density to be at 0.658 mm(2nd Octile) or better.
The continuum peak values are an extrapolation from the 100 micron feature detection obtained with the Herschel telescope assuming the emission from 100 microns to 1 mm follow thermal dust emission from large grains with a slope of 2.0 (Draine 2006). This estimated flux is a lower limit value.

Kepler-68 is a exosolar system with models suggesting that one of the planets (Kepler-68b) is likely composed of rock and water (Gilliland et. al 2013). Observations of this system will allow us to measure the amount of CO snowline emission with respect to the location of the icy planets. By comparing with the H2O line emission, we can test the water delivery system theories. These observations directly coincide with our overall aim of seeking the origins of water in the habitable zone.

Two spectral windows in the correlator are set to observe emission lines (a line per spectral window), with two additional spectral windows observing the continuum. The spectral line widths are not well restrained, thus we used the results obtained from ALMA observations of protoplanetary disks to obtain a lower limit to the line widths (Teague et al. 2015, Mathews et al. 2013).

We estimate that the exosolar systems will have a extent of 100 au; assuming the distances to the sources given in Table 1, we obtained largest angular scale structures ranging from 1.16 and 5.6 arcsecs. The chosen angular resolution of 0.58 which represents a 50 au from the host star. Ideally, this value would have been the distance to the habitable zone, however, ALMA early science is not yet capable of achieving resolution of 0.006 arcsecs within a reasonable time. The resolution we requested will allows us to distinguish between the inner and outer regions of the exosolar systems, enabling us to determine if the location of the snowline and water with respect to the location of the planets in the system.

We propose to observe four exosolar systems identified with known planets in and around the habitable zone. We will observe DCO+ v = 0 J = 3-2 (216.1158 GHz) and H2O v2 = 1 5 (5,0)-6(4,3) (232.6867 GHz) lines. Since these lines have yet to be detected in these early exosolar systems, we obtained the peak line flux value from the ALMA detection of the DCO+ line of HD 163296 (Mathews et al. 2013). Given that our sources are at a later evolutionary stage we are assuming the emission will be lower than for a protoplanetary disk, thus we estimated a value of 1.5 mJy for the peak line flux, after the continuum emission for HD 163296 at 1.3 mm was subtracted from the line detection obtained by Isella et al. (2013). In order to obtain a minimum of 5sigma detection, we set the requested sensitivity to 0.3 mJy, to achieve this sensitivity we also request the water vapor column density to be at 0.658 mm(2nd Octile) or better.
The continuum peak values are an extrapolation from the 100 micron feature detection obtained with the Herschel telescope assuming the emission from 100 microns to 1 mm follow thermal dust emission from large grains with a slope of 2.0 (Draine 2006). This estimated flux is a lower limit value.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Detecting water in an exosolar system with confirmed planets in their habitable zone is the next logical step in the search for Earth-like planets. We propose to study the water and CO snowline content present in four exosolar systems with known planets by using ALMA to obtain images of the DCO+ v=0 J=3-2 (at 216.1158 GHz) and H2O v2=1 5(5,0)-6(4,3) (at 232.6867 GHz) emission lines. Our sample will include four exosolar systems (< 200 pc) with confirmed exoplanets. Kepler-186 and Kepler-438 both have Earth-like planets with Kepler-186's Earth-like planet orbiting within in the habitable zone (Quintana 2014 et al. and Torres 2015 et al respectively). Kepler-444 is the oldest known exoplanetary system, with five sub-Earth planets (Campante et al. 2015), and Kepler-68 has a planet with the density of that equal to rock and water (Gilliland et al. 2013). This sample will allow us to determine the evolution and distribution of water and determine the CO snowline region of the exosolar system. ALMAs capabilities are ideally suited to take this next step in the search for life on other planets.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
